title: How to publish consistent open data
displayTitle: How to publish consistent open data
body:
In our first module we explored the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities. In this module we look at one of the biggest barriers to realising those benefits - inconsistent publishing approaches. Many authorities are unaware of the support available to them in publishing consistent, usable data.

Below you can learn about the benefits of following consistent publishing approaches, access the best resources to support you and understand a simple assessment checklist that can save hours of staff time in every release.

title: Why does consistency matter?
body:
Open data is not just a compliance exercise. The aim of all open data is to invite others to use the data, whether for a new app, a study or just to gain a deeper understanding. Most open data users will want more than one dataset. Often they combine datasets from different authorities. When combining datasets, consistency matters. Without consistent 'schemas' or column headings, users cannot easily combine your data with others. Without consistent availability

The traditional justification for this free service has been that authorities produce their open data through the operation of taxpayer-funded services.

However, gathering and maintaining data always has a cost attached to it. For this reason, in some cases local authorities may need to charge the user a small fee to cover any costs associated with the data. For this data to qualify as open, the cost should be no more than the 'reasonable reproduction cost' of the data involved. Authorities can charge a fee to cover the costs of supporting a user's data request but should not charge a premium for the data.

title: Finding the right schema
body: Before publishing an open dataset, there are three questions you need to ask yourself. Each of these questions can be answered through the tools available on LG Inform Plus. Click below to learn about each question and how to answer it.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Is there a standard schema for this dataset?
_items.body:
The first question you need to answer is whether there is already a schema for your dataset. A schema is a set of column headings in the dataset. The LGA keeps standard schemas for 10 of the most popular open datasets in their schema guides as well as more than 640 schema examples from authorities around the UK. By using a standard schema, your open data can be combined with other authorities' releases to build up regional and national overviews. Standard schemas also save you time and prevent your staff 'reinventing the wheel.

Using the standard schemas is simple. Just find the right schema for your dataset, rename you colunm heading to match and save the result. No common schema for the dataset you are publishing? Try to make your headings as simple as possible and then submit your own schema as the new standard.
Take me to LG Inform Plus Schemas Directory

_items.title: Does the dataset need cleaning up?
_items.body:
Knowing that your dataset is clean is important to ensure your users have a reliable starting point when working with it. Clean data is data that is consistent, free from duplication and blank cells and ready for machine consumption.

When you are looking for errors in data, it is useful to have tools at your fingertips to support your cleaning. We reccomend the use of OpenRefine which can help you quickly clean large datasets. It is also important to keep a note of what changes have been made and share these openly with others so that everyone, including other staff inside your authority, can benefit from your work.

To get started with OpenRefine, you can follow this ODI exercise. To download the free OpenRefine tool follow this link

_items.title: Where am I going to publish?
_items.body:
For publishers, the choice of a publishing location is important because it provides the pathway to your data for users. The longer that pathway or the harder it is to locate, the fewer people will walk down it. Many authorities choose to publish on their own websites and link the results to data.gov.uk. Others will choose to use a platform like CIPFA/Redbridge's Datashare, Swirrl's PublishMyData or CKAN to simplify the process of publishing.

Wherever you choose to publish, one thing to keep in mind is that your data should always be accessible from the homepage of your authority. The number of clicks doesn't matter but people should be able to find your data quickly from anywhere on your web presence.

title: When you publish - The key steps to a good open data release
displayTitle: When you publish - The key steps to a good open data release
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Local government has been releasing open data for years on everything from election results to the locations of public toilets. But why should authorities publish open data and what are the best arguements to persuade colleages?
instruction: Click on each of the boxes below to expand.

_items.title: 3. Validating the dataset
_items.body:
Once your data is uploaded and live, it is important to check that it meets the minimum standards for quality and usability which ensure that people can use it. The LGA has a quick validation tool that lets you check whether your data matches the quality and consistency guidelines of the DCLG transparency code.
Take me to the LGA Validator.

_items.title: 4. Adding the open licence
_items.body:
Once you know your dataset is valid and online, the most important thing is to place it under the correct licence. The licence is the only thing that can make your published data into open data. While local authorities can choose the licence they place on their dataset, we strongly recommend using the Open Government Licence (OGL) for all of your data. OGL is a simple, clear licence used by all government departments and many others. Placing one on your dataset takes only a few minutes. To apply your licence follow the link below.
Take me to the OGL page.

_items.title: 5. Providing a consistent URI
_items.body:
A URI or Uniform Resource Identifier is a web address that allows anyone to quickly and consistently locate your dataset. Putting a good URI on your dataset is an important step toward consistent publication. We reccomend using two URIs for any dataset you publish. The first should use the LGA's directory of common identifiers to refer to your local authority. This URI lets any machine or person find your dataset if they know the authority code. You can use the LGA directory to look up the correct code for your authority in seconds. The second URI should tell people, in the address bar, exactly what the dataset is. For example, a dataset from Hampshire county council about senior salaries might be under the secondary URI 'http://www3.hants.gov.uk/opendata/datasets/senior-salaries.htm'. This second URI lets anyone read what the dataset is before they navigate to it. This second URI should redirect to the main URI using the LGA directory.
Take me to LGAs URI directory.

_items.alt: Registering the dataset in a catalogue
_items.title: 6. Registering the dataset in a catalogue
_items.body:
The next step is to reference your data in a catalogue. There are two catalogues which it is important to add your data to. The first is data.gov.uk, the second in LG Inform. Data.gov.uk is the UK's national open data portal and has a huge community of users who turn data like yours into valuable results for the local area. Publishing on there will expose your dataset to national attention. LG Inform is the community resource for local authority data and allows your data to be combined with that of other authorities in order to cooperate and generate better results for you. Registering a dataset on data.gov.uk is a simple submission process where you complete key metadata information. Registration with LG Inform is automatic once you have an up-to-date inventory (see step 7)
Take me to the data.gov.uk dataset registration page.

_items.title: 7. Updating your inventory
_items.body:
An inventory lets other people know what data you have published. It encourages consistent referencing of datasets across councils to make it easier to find datasets on the same topic or in the same format. data.gov.uk has built a harvester to automatically import inventories and so maintain up-to-date entries for a council, in its index of UK open data. LGA provides guidance to help you update your inventory and publish it according to the correct specifications
Take me to the LGA inventories

title: After you publish - Getting an ODI Certificate
displayTitle: After you publish - Getting an ODI Certificate
body:
Now have a fully-compliant open dataset published, the final step in the process is to certify your results so that others can search for your data based on quality. For this process, LGA reccomends applying an ODI certificate to your dataset. ODI Open Data Certificates is a free online tool developed to assess and recognise the quality and sustainability of open datasets. The certificates are an independent quality marque designed to support open data publishers in acheiving professional results.

Open Data Certificates provide publishers with a range of benefits including:
  • Formal recognition of your data quality
  • A much broader user base
  • Automatic trust in the quality and usability of your data
  • Instant, simple compliance with the best publishing practices
  • Free advice on improving the quality of your data

title: What do Open Data Certificates look for?
displayTitle: What do Open Data Certificates look for?
body: ODI Open Data Certificates consider the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

title: How can I get an Open Data Certificate?
displayTitle: How can I get an Open Data Certificate?
body:
Getting your Open Data Certificate is simple.

First, you complete a short questionnaire to assess the level of support you provide for the data. Depending on the answers, the ODI awards a badge that can be embedded on your website to signify the quality level of your publication.

If you are publishing your data in a machine readable way (for example, by using a data portal like ckan), the site can pre-fill many of the certificate questions. Just enter the URL on the first page to get started.
Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates Site

title: Are you ready for the benefits of open data publishing?
displayTitle: Are you ready for the benefits of open data publishing?
body: Can you recall these four things about the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities?

title: Things to check before you publish
displayTitle: Things to check before you publish
body: Which of the following should you check before publishing your dataset?
instruction: Select up to three options, then click 'Submit'.

_items.text: Whether there is a common schema
How large the data file will be
Where the dataset will be published
When the data will be available

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Three essential considerations before publishing your dataset are whether a common schema exists, whether the dataset is clean and where the data will be published.

_incorrect.notFinal:

title: Licensing your dataset
body: When publishing your dataset, what licence does LGA reccomend you apply to the dataset?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

LGA reccomends that all data published by authorities is under the Open Government Licence because it is the simplest and most accessible license for your data

title: Technical considerations in ODI Certificates
body: There are three technical considerations as part of the ODi Certificates standards for publishing open data, one of which is...

_items.text: What format the open data is published in.
Whether it can it be used on a computer.
Whether it takes up much bandwidth.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

title: How to publish consistent open data
displayTitle: How to publish consistent open data
body:
In this module we have explored all the steps to publishing consistent, high-quality open data for your authority. Follow the guidance above and you will produce highly usable data which can generate signifiact impact for your authority as well as saving you time and money

In our next and final module, we will look at where you can find the best examples of authorities who have followed this guidance and see how their publication helped them acheive results.
